creditline: Gift of funds from the Print and Drawing Council
text: Alnauld-Eloi, the son of Jacques Fabien Gautier-D'Agoty (whose ‘Angel woman’ is on display in the next room) retained the royal privilege for the exclusive right to print in color by his father in 1742. In the book from which this page comes, the human figure is represented progressively stripped of its layers of skin and flesh. This illustration is among the last ones: the male flayed poses like a skinny pin-up to show its bones and a few muscles.
title: Flayed Skeleton, from Cours complet d'anatomie, published Nancy, 1773
